title.narrative: The Gender and Justice Project/Atlantic initiative
The Gender and Justice Project/Atlantic initiative

description.narrative: Atlantic Initiative is a local NGO established in 2009. Since 2015, it is a partner in the predecessor Project "Gender and Justice Reform" implemented by DCAF (Geneva Centre for Democratic Control of Armed Forces) which is supported by Sida with 5 000 000 SEK. This Project ended in April 2017. After a successful end of this Project, confirmed by several events organized with partners to the Project, Atlantic Initiative is applying on its own to the Embassy with the aim to support the BiH justice sector address issues of gender based discrimination and violence against women. The Project duration is from August 2017 to August 2019 and the amount of support is up to 4 300 000 SEK.

Atlantic Initiative är en NGO som etablerades 2009. Sedan 2015 är Atlantic Initiative partner i projektet "Gender and Justice Reform" som implementerades av DCAF (Geneva Centre for Democratic Control of Armed Forces). Sida har bidragit med 5 000 000 SEK till projktet. Projektet avslutades i april 2017.
Efter ett framgångsrikt projekt, vilket har bekräftas genom flera evenemang som anordnats med partners, har Atlantic Initiative skickat in en ansökan till ambassaden med syfte att stödja BiH rättsväsende gällande frågor om jämställdhetdiskriminering och våld mot kvinnor. Projekt varaktighet föreslås mellan augusti 2017 till augusti 2019 med stöd av 4 300 000 SEK.

The Atlantic Initiative (AI) received approval from the Embassy for a 2 year project to address gender inequality in BiH judiciary. The project started August 2017. The project was extended until end June 2020 to implement additional activities and in July 2020 extended again until 15 November with sole purpose to undertake a Project evaluation. The Project aimed to support the protection of women's rights in the justice system, particularly in proceedings involving domestic violence, rape and sexual harassment. The project aimed to build the capacities of judges and prosecutors to understand and apply gender equality in their work while simultaneously changing institutional cultures toward greater gender sensitivity and responsiveness. The project included intensive work with judicial community and collaborative resource development, workshops, court visits, policy initiatives, development of professional Bench books, research and analysis. The Project established synergies between policies, practice and academia and made qualitative changes of both judicial practice and law schools' teaching when it comes to gender and justice. The project focused intensively on strengthening adjudication of domestic violence cases, rape cases and sexual harassment cases. In addition, the project enabled sustainable implementation of sexual harassment policies. Further the project focused on supporting judiciary in identifying, understanding and overcoming biases related to gender in cases of violence against women and in cases related to family law. The project moved away from presenting gender as a single category and instead explored challenges in accessing justice for women with disabilities and Roma women. Through the project implementation strong cooperation with media was developed. The project also included training for journalists for writing and reporting on gender based violence which resulted in number of in depth stories published in print and online media.

description.narrative: The following results are summarized by the Atlantic Initiative in its final reporting and have been independently verified by the Final evaluation. 1. Domestic violence: visits to courts and critical review of domestic violencejudgments The project proposal envisioned 20 smaller courts visits in total - over the two-yearproject period. In previous reporting period we conducted 17 courts visits reaching more than 220 judges and court staff. In May 2020, one online workshop was organized instead of a court visit, to the Prijedor District Court), while two remaining smaller court visits were not organized due to COVID-19 pandemicThe study Gender Bias and Judiciary, which was completed by the Project in 2020, indicates changes in views of respondents concerning sentencing policy in DV cases and elaboration of court decisions 2. Sexual harassment: adjudication of sexual harassment cases and support to advisors Training curriculum on adjudication of sexual harassment cases that was developed in 2019 and published in 2020 by the Atlantic Initiative, is used as a training material by judges and prosecutors who delivered trainings on the sexual and gender based harassment in June 2020. The training, initially scheduled in April 2020 on was organised online in jointcooperation of entity training centres and was attended by 17 participants - 8 from Federation of BiH and 9 from Republika Srpska. In close cooperation with High Judicial and Prosecutorial Council, the Atlantic Initiative monitors cases of sexual harassment on the regular basis and follows appointments of new advisors. According to Gender Bias and the Judiciary research, which was completed in 2020 as part of the Project, most respondents – judicial professionals, 73% said that they were informed about sexual harassment (SH) prevention policies and other anti-discrimination policies in their institutions, while 13% said that they were not. Most respondents said that they were informed through trainings and regular annual meetings in their institutions. Compared to previous research, in 2013, there was a considerable increase in this respect, as 44% had then said that they were informed about pertinent internal policies. Moreover, the same 2020 research indicated a 10% decrease in the number of respondents who said that they witnessed inappropriate jokes and comments in their work environments. 3. Strengthening the responses to non-war-related rape cases Handbook for processing rape cases, which was developed in 2018 by the project as a joint endeavour by judges, academic, NGO received the most positive reviews for its relevance, richness, depth and practical use in justice sector. Within this project phase, the Atlantic Initiative managed to include Handbook related trainings on rape cases into JPTCs’ regular training programmes for 2020. 4. Consideration of judicial practice in family law cases Family law is an area with many new developments over the past decades, some of which had different implications on women and men, and persons with disabilities, and carried high risk of gender bias (e.g. emerging issues of joint custody of children, same sex partnerships, marriage of persons with disability, adoption by single women, adoption by persons with disability, and so on). The Atlantic Initiative finalised in early 2020 and published in June 2020 Family Law Handbook[1], as one of the first materials on the subject of gender and family law ever published in BiH 5. Research on access to justice for members of the Roma community In June 2020 the Research was finalised with the support of Roma researchers. This research included more than 150 respondents, largely members of the Roma community, but also judicial professionals. The research results in findings related to Roma perceptions of police and judicial work, processing of DV cases, and judges’ positions regarding members of the Roma community. Recommendations are given to police agencies, judicial institutions and non-governmental organizations working on Roma issues. This research shows that Roma women feel discriminated when compared with the rest of population. The research also implies significantly higher participation of Roma man in public life and communications with institutions in general compared to Roma women.
